awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT:  Limiting agricultural loss due to powdery mildew disease
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project is to reduce agricultural loss due to powdery mildew. The wine and grape industry is a multi-billion dollar industry which is heavily impacted by powdery mildew disease that reduces yield and product quality, resulting in an 'off' flavor. For grapes, powdery mildew treatment represents 75% of pesticide costs, and current treatment methods are becoming less effective. Every grape-bearing acre is treated numerous times in a growing season, typically with sulfur treatments interspersed with the use of systemic fungicides (chemicals that inhibit powdery mildew protein function). However, resistance to currently used fungicides is increasingly common and recent reports suggest that sulfur poses health risks. We are using a non-GMO approach called RNAi (RNA interference) which limits the production of specific powdery mildew chemicals in an environmentally friendly process.  In addition, the market for the proposed products will be further explored, and a detailed commercialization plan will be developed with active input from commercialization experts and industry stakeholders. Training in entrepreneurship of women and minorities is an important component of this project, which is led by women and will include women and minority Agriculture Innovation Undergraduate Interns.

The proposed project will address the pressing and widespread problem of powdery mildew disease of agriculture, focused on grapevine. Powdery mildew is a ubiquitous pathogen of grapevine that has a major impact on yield and product quality. The team developed a non-GMO RNAi approach to limit the function of specific powdery mildew genes and the means to screen for the targets that most efficiently result in decreased disease on plants. In this proposal, the team will screen for additional novel powdery mildew targets and perform field testing of at least one highly promising RNAi product. Novel powdery mildew targets can be readily identified using this approach and grapevine treatment with distinct RNAi products over the course of the growing season can provide a cost-effective and safer means of limiting powdery mildew disease.  RNAi products are biodegradable and highly specific with minimal off-targets, making them attractive as more environmentally benign than current treatments.  Intellectual property for the target identification process and efficacious powdery mildew targets will be secured.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This NSF PFI-TT project addressed the pressing and widespread problem of powdery mildew in agriculture, focused on grapevine.  Powdery mildew is a ubiquitous fungal pathogen of grapevine that has a major impact on yield and product quality. All productive grapevines are treated throughout the growing season to control powdery mildew, and this treatment represents 75% of pesticide costs. Current treatment methods are becoming less effective as powdery mildew resistance has emerged against commonly employed fungicides. Furthermore, the use of some fungicides is being restricted due to human health and/or environmental concerns.

To address this problem, we leveraged our extensive knowledge of the powdery mildew-plant host interaction, previously funded by NSF, to develop a novel biocontrol approach to limit powdery mildew proliferation. Through the NSF national Innovation-Corps program, we explored the powdery mildew control customer/market ecosystem to identify our optimal first target market (powdery mildew of grapevine), the detailed needs of the end-user, and our value proposition.

We used spray-induced gene silencing (SIGS) in which double-stranded RNA specific to a portion of the powdery mildew gene of interest is topically applied (sprayed) on the plant. We showed the RNA is taken up by the fungus and using an existing system of RNA interference, it limits the production of the targeted powdery mildew protein. We developed and optimized this system for the grape powdery mildew- grapevine interaction, the methodology for powdery mildew gene target selection and screening to identify those powdery mildew targets that when silenced most effectively limit powdery mildew proliferation.

We identified a number of novel highly effective powdery midlew targets for powdery mildew control using grapevine greenhouse studies. We then tested four of them in grapevine field trials at two locations using standard randomized block design methods, with consultation from University of California Extension Specialists. These treatments effectively limited powdery mildew disease when compared to untreated plants, kept grape disease severity to below acceptable thresholds, and were as effective as the gold standard commercial fungicide treatments. Furthermore, there was no phytotoxicity or observed impact on plant/grape development.

Our RNA products are biodegradable and highly specific to the powdery mildew gene targeted, minimizing environmental and health risks. Patents covering our system and targets have been filed. Given the initial success of our SIGS treatments against powdery mildew of grapevine in the field, we initiated development of a commercialization plan with active input from commercialization experts and industry stakeholders. Training in both molecular plant pathology and entrepreneurship of women and minorities has been an important component of this project, which is led by three women and has trained seven Agriculture Innovation UC Berkeley undergraduate Interns (5 female, 3 underrepresented minorities) building our workforce of diverse scientist entrepreneurs.

 


Last Modified: 12/07/2022
Modified by: Mary C Wildermuth
